flashcards.english: Gacukari, Gathumo, Gatumia, Kambara, Kĩbuda, Kĩganda, Mbiri, Mũraru, Mũtahato, Mũtore, Njuru (gacuru, mũcũru), Nyoro, Wanga'e
flashcards.notes: Traditional Kikuyu names and cultural terms. Marigũ ma Mũgĩkũyũ = traditional Kikuyu words/names. Cultural heritage vocabulary

flashcards.english: Mũndĩ/bundi (handyman - carpenter/plumber), Mũrĩmi (farmer), Ndereba (driver), Atongoria (leaders), Borithi (police), Mũũbĩa (priest-catholic), Mũhũrĩri wa mbica (photographer), Mũgwĩmi (hunter), Mũrĩithia wa mahiũ (herder), Aturi (iron mongers), Ombi a nyũngũ (potters), Mũgo (medicine person)
flashcards.notes: Complete professions vocabulary. Work pattern: (Person) arutaga wĩra wa (verb). Examples: Ndũtaga wĩra wa mbao (I work with timber), Mũrutaga wĩra wa gũtongoria andũ (lead people), Marutaga wĩra wa kũnyita andũ (arrest people)

flashcards.english: Aciari (parents), Rũrĩrĩ (community/tribe speaking one language), Ciana (children), Kenda mũiyũrũ (the full nine/ten), Tũhĩĩ (boys), Tũirĩtu (girls), Nyũmba (house/woman's hut), Thingira (men's hut), Ikũmbĩ (granary), Mũgũnda (garden/farm), Gĩcagi (village)
flashcards.notes: Origin story of Kikuyu people: Gĩkũyũ na Mũũmbi had 9 daughters (kenda = 9, but kenda mũiyũrũ = full nine/ten). Traditional dwelling vocabulary: Nyũmba (woman's), Thingira (men's), Ikũmbĩ (granary)

flashcards.english: Heho (cold), Ũrugarĩ (heat/warmth), Mwaki (fire), Gĩchĩnga (smoldering stick with fire), Burana (cardigan/sweater), Ĩgooti (coat), Kabuti (overcoat), Mũrĩngĩti (blanket), Ĩkĩra (put/put on/wear), Kwĩhũmba (to wear), Mũno (very much)
flashcards.notes: Weather and clothing vocabulary. Kaĩ = question prefix, adding 'ĩ' at end makes emphatic statement: Kaĩ kwĩna heho? (Is it cold?) → Kaĩ kwĩna heho-ĩ! (It is really cold!). Mweri wa mũgwanja = July (7th month), usually very cold

flashcards.english: Guka/Wagui (Grandfather - Muranga/Kiambu vs Nyeri), Cũcũ (Grandmother), Tata (Aunt), Mama (Uncle-mother's side), Baba mũnini (Uncle-father's younger brother), Baba mũkũrũ (Uncle-father's older brother), Mũrũ wa tata (Cousin-aunt's son), Mũrũ wa mama (Cousin-uncle's son), Mũrũ wa maitũ (Brother), Mwarĩ wa maitũ (Sister), Mũrũ wa baba (Half Brother), Mwarĩ wa baba (Half Sister)
flashcards.notes: Complete family system. Regional variation: Guka (Muranga/Kiambu) vs Wagui (Nyeri) for grandfather. Note: All father's brothers' wives are addressed as 'mother'. Half-siblings specified by 'wa baba' (father's child from another wife)

flashcards.english: Ikinya (foot/step), Ihenya (race), Kĩnya (gourd), Kinya (arrive/step on/up to), Hinya (strength), Menya (know), Kunya (pinch), Nyanya (tomato), Munya (uproot), Hihinya (squeeze/press)
flashcards.notes: Minimal pairs and homophones demonstrating importance of tone and vowel length. Shows semantic range from body parts (ikinya) to actions (kinya, kunya, munya) to objects (kĩnya, nyanya)

flashcards.english: Mbata (duck), Ngũkũ ya mwera (hen), Gacui (chick), Ngũkũ ya njamba (cock), Nyamũ ya thĩ (snake - polite/euphemistic)
flashcards.notes: Poultry vocabulary with gender distinction: ya mwera (female/hen) vs ya njamba (male/cock). Cultural note: Nyamũ ya thĩ (animal of the ground) is polite way to refer to snake - avoids attracting it to your house by saying its direct name
